Which statements are correct for ionic compounds?

II.  Within the same group, the melting point of salts tends to decrease as the radius of the cation increases.

B. I and III only


C. II and III only


D. I, II and III

questions.content: Plot the relative values of the first four ionization energies of sodium.

markscheme:

Award mark only if the energy difference between the first two points is larger than that between points 2/3 and 3/4.

questions.label: b

all are s1[✔]

questions.label: c

electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
OR
electrostatic attraction between Na+ and O2− ions [✔]

questions.content:
Calculate values for the following changes using section 8 of the data booklet.



ΔHatomisation (Na) = 107 kJ mol−1
ΔHatomisation (O) = 249 kJ mol−1


1 2 O2(g) → O2- (g):


Na (s) → Na+ (g):
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: 1 2 O2(g) → O2- (g)
«ΔHatomisation (O) + 1st EA + 2nd EA = 249 k Jmol−1 − 141 kJmol−1 + 753 kJmol−1 =» «+»861 «kJmol−1» [✔]
Na (s) → Na+ (g)
«ΔHatomisation (Na) + 1st IE = 107 kJmol−1 + 496 kJmol−1 =» «+»603 «kJmol−1» [✔]

questions.content:
The standard enthalpy of formation of sodium oxide is −414 kJ mol−1. Determine the lattice enthalpy of sodium oxide, in kJ mol−1, using section 8 of the data booklet and your answers to (d)(i).



(If you did not get answers to (d)(i), use +850 kJ mol−1 and +600 kJ mol−1 respectively, but these are not the correct answers.)
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme: «= +» 2481 «kJ mol−1» [✔]
Note:Award [2] for correct final answer.

If given values are used:
M1: lattice enthalpy = 850 «kJ mol−1» +
2× 600 «kJ mol−1» −(−414 «kJ mol−1»)
M2: «= +» 2464 «kJ mol−1»

questions.content: Justify why K2O has a lower lattice enthalpy (absolute value) than Na2O.
questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: K+ ion is larger than Na+
smaller attractive force because of greater distance between ion «centres» [✔]

Phosphorus(V) oxide, P4O10:


Differentiation:

Phosphorus(V) oxide:
P4O10 (s) + 6H2O(l) → 4H3PO4 (aq) [✔]

NaOH/product of Na2O is alkaline/basic/pH > 7 AND H3PO4/product of P4O10 is acidic/pH < 7 [✔]

questions.content:
Sodium peroxide, Na2O2, is formed by the reaction of sodium oxide with oxygen.


2Na2O (s) + O2 (g) → 2Na2O2 (s)


Calculate the percentage yield of sodium peroxide if 5.00g of sodium oxide produces 5.50g of sodium peroxide.
questions.label: f
markscheme: n(Na2O2) theoretical yield «= 5.00 g 61.98 g mo l − 1 » = 0.0807/8.07 × 10−2 «mol»
mass of Na2O2 theoretical yield «= 5.00 g 61.98 g mo l − 1 × 77.98 gmol−1» = 6.291 «g» [✔]
% yield «= 5.50 g 6.291 g × 100» OR « 0.0705 0.0807 ×100» = 87.4 «%» [✔]

questions.content: Determine the enthalpy change, ΔH, in kJ, for this reaction using data from the table and section 12 of the data booklet.
questions.label: g(i)
markscheme: ∑ΔHfreactants = 2 × (−510.9) + 2 × (−393.5) / −1808.8 «kJ» [✔]
ΔH= «∑ΔHf products − ∑ΔHf reactants = −2261.4 −(−1808.8) =» −452.6 «kJ» [✔]

16N.2.hl.TZ0.1b.excerpt: (i) Calculate ΔHθ, in kJ, for this similar reaction below using   Δ      H                  f              θ   data from section 12 of the data booklet.   Δ      H                  f              θ   of HOCH2CH2OH(l) is –454.8kJmol-1.2CO (g) + 3H2 (g)   ⇌ HOCH2CH2OH (l)(ii) Deduce why the answers to (a)(iii) and (b)(i) differ.(iii) ΔSθ for the reaction in (b)(i) is –620.1JK-1. Comment on the decrease in entropy.(iv) Calculate the value of ΔGθ, in kJ, for this reaction at 298 K using your answer to (b)(i). (If you did not obtain an answer to (b)(i), use –244.0 kJ, but this is not the correct value.)(v) Comment on the statement that the reaction becomes less spontaneous as temperature is increased.
specification: Ethane-1,2-diol, HOCH2CH2OH, has a wide variety of uses including the removal of ice from aircraft and heat transfer in a solar cell.

questions.content:
(i) Calculate ΔHθ, in kJ, for this similar reaction below using \(\Delta H_{\rm{f}}^\theta \) data from section 12 of the data booklet. \(\Delta H_{\rm{f}}^\theta \) of HOCH2CH2OH(l) is –454.8kJmol-1.


2CO (g) + 3H2 (g) \( \rightleftharpoons \) HOCH2CH2OH (l)


(ii) Deduce why the answers to (a)(iii) and (b)(i) differ.


(iii) ΔSθ for the reaction in (b)(i) is –620.1JK-1. Comment on the decrease in entropy.


(iv) Calculate the value of ΔGθ, in kJ, for this reaction at 298 K using your answer to (b)(i). (If you did not obtain an answer to (b)(i), use –244.0 kJ, but this is not the correct value.)


(v) Comment on the statement that the reaction becomes less spontaneous as temperature is increased.
questions.label: b
markscheme:
i
«ΔH = Σ ΔHf products –ΣΔHf reactants = –454.8 kJ mol-1– 2(–110.5 kJ mol-1) =» –233.8 «kJ»

ii
in (a)(iii) gas is formed and in (b)(i) liquid is formed
OR
products are in different states
OR
conversion of gas to liquid is exothermic
OR
conversion of liquid to gas is endothermic
OR
enthalpy of vapourisation needs to be taken into account

Accept product is «now» a liquid.
Accept answers referring to bond enthalpies being means/averages.

iii
«ΔS is negative because five mols of» gases becomes «one mol of» liquid
OR
increase in complexity of product «compared to reactants»
OR
product more ordered «than reactants»
Accept “fewer moles of gas” but not “fewer molecules”.

Award [2] for correct final answer.
Award [1 max] for «+»185 × 103.

If –244.0 kJ used, answer is:
ΔG = –244.0 kJ –(298 K \(\left( {\frac{{ - 620.1}}{{1000}}} \right)\)kJ K-1) = –59.2 «kJ»
Award [2] for correct final answer.

v
increasing T makes ΔG larger/more positive/less negative
OR
–TΔS will increase

questions.content:
The table shows the variation of standard Gibbs energy with temperature for a reversible reaction.


∆G⦵=∆H⦵-T∆S⦵


∆G⦵=-RT ln K



What can be concluded about the reaction?


A.  Equilibrium shifts left as temperature increases.


B.  The forward reaction is more spontaneous below 300 K.


C.  Entropy is higher in the products than in the reactants.


D.  Kc decreases as temperature increases.

specification: Hydrogen peroxide can react with methane and oxygen to form methanol. This reaction can occur below 50°C if a gold nanoparticle catalyst is used.

Now consider the second stage of the reaction.
CO (g) + 2H2 (g) ⇌ CH3OH (l)          ΔH⦵ = –129 kJ
Hydrogen peroxide can react with methane and oxygen to form methanol. This reaction can occur below 50°C if a gold nanoparticle catalyst is used.

Methanol is usually manufactured from methane in a two-stage process.
CH4 (g) + H2O (g) ⇌ CO (g) + 3H2 (g)CO (g) + 2H2 (g) ⇌ CH3OH (l)

Consider the first stage of the reaction.
CH4 (g) + H2O (g) ⇌ CO (g) + 3H2 (g)

markscheme: new/catalysed Ea marked AND to the left of Ea of curve T1 ✔

Do not penalize curve missing a label, not passing exactly through the origin, or crossing x-axis after Ea.

Accept Ea drawn to T1 instead of curve drawn as long as to left of marked Ea.

specification: Limestone can be converted into a variety of useful commercial products through the lime cycle. Limestone contains high percentages of calcium carbonate, CaCO3.

Ca(OH)2 (aq) + CO2 (g) → CaCO3 (s) + H2O (l)

specification: Limestone can be converted into a variety of useful commercial products through the lime cycle. Limestone contains high percentages of calcium carbonate, CaCO3.
Thermodynamic data for the decomposition of calcium carbonate is given.
The second step of the lime cycle produces calcium hydroxide, Ca(OH)2.

Calcium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide to reform calcium carbonate.
Ca(OH)2 (aq) + CO2 (g) → CaCO3 (s) + H2O (l)

questions.content:
Calcium carbonate is heated to produce calcium oxide, CaO.


CaCO3 (s) → CaO (s) + CO2 (g)


Calculate the volume of carbon dioxide produced at STP when 555 g of calcium carbonate decomposes. Use sections 2 and 6 of the data booklet.
questions.label: a
markscheme: Accept method using pV = nRT to obtain the volume with p as either 100 kPa (126 dm3) or 101.3 kPa (125 dm3).
Do not penalize use of 22.4 dm3 mol–1 to obtain the volume (124 dm3).

questions.content: Calculate the enthalpy change of reaction, ΔH, in kJ, for the decomposition of calcium carbonate.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: Ignore an extra step to determine total enthalpy change in kJ: 179 kJ mol-1 x 5.55 mol = 993 kJ.
Award [2] for an answer in the range 990 - 993« kJ».

questions.content: Calculate the change in entropy, ΔS, in J K−1, for the decomposition of calcium carbonate.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: Ignore an extra step to determine total entropy change in JK–1: 161 J mol–1K–1 x 5.55 mol = 894 «J mol–1K–1»

questions.content:
Determine the temperature, in K, at which the decomposition of calcium carbonate becomes spontaneous, using b(i), b(ii) and section 1 of the data booklet.


(If you do not have answers for b(i) and b(ii), use ΔH = 190 kJ and ΔS = 180 J K−1, but these are not the correct answers.)
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: Accept “1056 K” if both of the incorrect values are used to solve the problem.
Do not award M2 for any negative T value.

questions.content: Sketch an energy profile for the decomposition of calcium carbonate based on your answer to b(i), labelling the axes and activation energy, Ea.
questions.label: b(iv)
markscheme: x-axis labelled “extent of reaction/progress of reaction/reaction coordinate/reaction pathway” AND y-axis labelled “potential energy/energy/enthalpy✓

questions.content: State how adding a catalyst to the reaction would impact the enthalpy change of reaction, ΔH, and the activation energy, Ea.
questions.label: b(v)

questions.content: Write the equation for the reaction of Ca(OH)2 (aq) with hydrochloric acid, HCl (aq).
questions.label: c(i)

questions.content: Determine the volume, in dm3, of 0.015 mol dm−3 calcium hydroxide solution needed to neutralize 35.0 cm3 of 0.025 mol dm−3 HCl (aq).
questions.label: c(ii)

questions.content: Saturated calcium hydroxide solution is used to test for carbon dioxide. Calculate the pH of a 2.33 × 10−2 mol dm−3 solution of calcium hydroxide, a strong base.
questions.label: c(iii)

questions.content: Determine the mass, in g, of CaCO3 (s) produced by reacting 2.41 dm3 of 2.33 × 10−2 mol dm−3 of Ca(OH)2 (aq) with 0.750 dm3 of CO2 (g) at STP.
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: Only award ECF for M2 if limiting reagent is used.

questions.content:
2.85 g of CaCO3 was collected in the experiment in d(i). Calculate the percentage yield of CaCO3.


(If you did not obtain an answer to d(i), use 4.00 g, but this is not the correct value.)
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme: Accept “71.3 %” for using the incorrect given value of 4.00 g.

questions.content: Outline how one calcium compound in the lime cycle can reduce a problem caused by acid deposition.
questions.label: e
markscheme:
«add» Ca(OH)2/CaCO3/CaO AND to «acidic» water/river/lake/soil
OR
«use» Ca(OH)2/CaCO3/CaO in scrubbers «to prevent release of acidic pollution» ✓
Accept any correct name for any of the calcium compounds listed.

B.     If ΔH > 0, reaction is never spontaneous.

D.     If ΔS < 0, reaction can be spontaneous if temperature is high enough.

22M.2.hl.TZ1.3c(iii).excerpt: Calculate the entropy change for the Haber–Bosch process, in J mol–1 K–1 at 298 K. Use your answer to (b)(i) and section 1 of the data booklet.
specification:
Ammonia is produced by the Haber–Bosch process which involves the equilibrium:
N2 (g) + 3 H2 (g) ⇌ 2 NH3 (g)
The percentage of ammonia at equilibrium under various conditions is shown:

[The Haber Bosch Process [graph] Available at: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ammonia_yield.png[Accessed: 16/07/2022].]
One factor affecting the position of equilibrium is the enthalpy change of the reaction.
The standard free energy change, ΔG⦵, for the Haber–Bosch process is –33.0 kJ at 298 K.

questions.content: Deduce the expression for the equilibrium constant, Kc, for this equation.
questions.label: a(i)

questions.content: State how the use of a catalyst affects the position of the equilibrium.
questions.label: a(ii)

questions.content: With reference to the reaction quotient, Q, explain why the percentage yield increases as the pressure is increased at constant temperature.
questions.label: a(iii)
markscheme:
Q becomes less than Kc
OR
affects the lower line/denominator of Q expression more than upper line/numerator ✔

«for Q to once again equal Kc,» ratio of products to reactants increases
OR
«for Q to once again equal Kc,» equilibrium shifts to right/products ✔
Award [2 max] for answers that do not refer to Q.

questions.content: Determine the enthalpy change, ΔH, for the Haber–Bosch process, in kJ. Use Section 11 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: «N-H» bond enthalpy is an average «and may not be the precise value in NH3» ✔
Accept ΔHf data are more accurate / are not average values.

questions.content: Demonstrate that your answer to (b)(i) is consistent with the effect of an increase in temperature on the percentage yield, as shown in the graph.
questions.label: b(iii)
markscheme: increased temperature decreases yield «as shown on graph» ✔

questions.content: State, giving a reason, whether the reaction is spontaneous or not at 298 K.
questions.label: c(i)

questions.content: Calculate the value of the equilibrium constant, K, at 298 K. Use sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet.
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme: Accept answers in the range 4.4×105 to 6.2×105 (arises from rounding of ln K).

questions.content: Calculate the entropy change for the Haber–Bosch process, in J mol–1 K–1 at 298 K. Use your answer to (b)(i) and section 1 of the data booklet.

19M.2.hl.TZ2.2g(ii).excerpt: Dinitrogen monoxide has a positive standard enthalpy of formation, ΔHfθ.Deduce, giving reasons, whether altering the temperature would change the spontaneity of the decomposition reaction.
specification:
The thermal decomposition of dinitrogen monoxide occurs according to the equation:
2N2O (g) → 2N2 (g) + O2 (g)
The reaction can be followed by measuring the change in total pressure, at constant temperature, with time.
The x-axis and y-axis are shown with arbitrary units.

This decomposition obeys the rate expression:

  −
  
    
      d
      [
      
        
          
            N
          
          2
        
      
      
        O]
      
    
    
      d
      t
    
  
 = k[N2O]

questions.content: Explain why, as the reaction proceeds, the pressure increases by the amount shown.
questions.label: a
markscheme: increase in the amount/number of moles/molecules «of gas» [✔]

questions.content: Outline, in terms of collision theory, how a decrease in pressure would affect the rate of reaction.
questions.label: b
markscheme:
«rate of reaction decreases»
concentration/number of molecules in a given volume decreases
OR
more space between molecules [✔]

collision rate/frequency decreases
OR
fewer collisions per unit time [✔]
Note:Do not accept just “larger space/volume” for M1.

questions.content: Deduce how the rate of reaction at t = 2 would compare to the initial rate.
questions.label: c(i)

questions.content:
It has been suggested that the reaction occurs as a two-step process:


Step 1: N2O (g) → N2 (g) + O (g)


Step 2: N2O (g) + O (g) → N2 (g) + O2 (g)


Explain how this could support the observed rate expression.
questions.label: c(ii)
markscheme:
1 slower than 2
OR
1 rate determinant step/RDS [✔]

1 is unimolecular/involves just one molecule so it must be first order
OR
if 1 faster/2 RDS, second order in N2O
OR
if 1 faster/2 RDS, first order in O [✔]

questions.content:
The experiment is repeated using the same amount of dinitrogen monoxide in the same apparatus, but at a lower temperature.


Sketch, on the axes in question 2, the graph that you would expect.
questions.label: d
markscheme: initial pressure is lowerANDfinal pressure of gas lower «by similar factor» [✔]

questions.content:
The experiment gave an error in the rate because the pressure gauge was inaccurate.


Outline whether repeating the experiment, using the same apparatus, and averaging the results would reduce the error.
questions.label: e
markscheme: no AND it is a systematic error/not a random error
no AND «a similar magnitude» error would occur every time [✔]

questions.content:
The graph below shows the Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution of molecular energies at a particular temperature.



The rate at which dinitrogen monoxide decomposes is significantly increased by a metal oxide catalyst.


Annotate and use the graph to outline why a catalyst has this effect.
questions.label: f
markscheme: catalysed and uncatalysed Ea marked on graph AND with the catalysed being at lower energy [✔]

«for catalysed reaction» greater proportion of/more molecules have E ≥ Ea / E > Ea
OR
«for catalysed reaction» greater area under curve to the right of the Ea [✔]
Note:Accept “more molecules have the activation energy”.

questions.content:
Determine the standard entropy change, in J K−1, for the decomposition of dinitrogen monoxide.


2N2O (g) → 2N2 (g) + O2 (g)
questions.label: g(i)
markscheme:
ΔSθ = 2(Sθ(N2)) + Sθ(O2) – 2(Sθ(N2O))
OR
ΔSθ = 2 × 193 «J mol-1 K-1» + 205 «J mol-1 K-1» – 2 × 220 «J mol-1 K-1» [✔]
«ΔSθ = +»151 «J K-1» [✔]

questions.content:
Dinitrogen monoxide has a positive standard enthalpy of formation, ΔHfθ.


Deduce, giving reasons, whether altering the temperature would change the spontaneity of the decomposition reaction.

markscheme:
TΔSθ > ΔHθ
OR
ΔGθ «= ΔHθ – TΔSθ» < 0 «at all temperatures» [✔]
reaction spontaneous at all temperatures [✔]
